General Utilities¶

General utilities are gathered in MyTools

Created on Nov 25, 2015

@author: Reuma

Methods

Utils.MyTools.CreateFilename(filename, mode='w', **kwargs)[source]¶
Checks or creates a file object according to specifications given.
Default is hdf5.

Warning

Need to be implemented for other formats than hdf5

Parameters:
  • filename (str) – can be a filename or a path and filename, with or without extension.
  • mode (str) – is an optional string that specifies the mode in which the file is opened. It defaults to ‘w’ which means open for writing in text mode.
  • extension (str) – ‘h5’, ‘json’, ‘shp’, ‘pts’, etc…
Returns:

a file object (according to the extension) and its extension
Utils.MyTools.DoG_filter(image, **kwargs)[source]¶

Compute the difference of gaussians filter. :param image: the image :param sigma1, sigma2: the sigma to be used for blurring. cv2 will decide the size accordingly. :param ksize1, ksize2: the size of the filter to be used for blurring. cv2 will decide the sigma accordingly. :return: filtered image

Utils.MyTools.ballTree_saliency(pointset, scale, neighborhood_properties, curvature_attribute, leaf_size=10, weight_distance=1, weight_normals=1, verbose=False)[source]¶

Compute curvature based saliency using ball-tree and k-nearest-neighbors.

The saliency for every set of points within a ball-tree cell is computed as one for all points.

See also

SaliencyFactory.curvature_saliency()

Parameters:
  • pointset (np.ndarray, PointSet.PointSet, BallTreePointSet.BallTreePointSet, PointSetOpen3D.PointSetOpen3D) – a point cloud of any sort
  • scale (float) – the scale of the minimal phenomena (size of the smallest ball-tree cell)
  • neighborhood_properties (int or float) – k nearest neighbors
  • curvature_attribute – the attribute according to which the curvature is measured.
  • leaf_size (int) – the minimum number of points in the ball tree leaves. Default: 10
  • weight_distance (float) – weights for distance element. Default: 1.
  • weight_normals (float) – weights for normal element. Default: 1.
  • verbose (bool) – print running messages. Default: False
Returns:

curvature property, normals property, saliency property
Return type:

CurvatureProperty, NormalsProperty, SaliencyProperty
Utils.MyTools.chi2_distance(histA, histB, eps=1e-10)[source]¶

Compute the \(\chi^2\) distance between two histograms

\[D_{\chi^2}(hist_A, hist_B) = \sum_{n=0}^N \frac{\left(hist_A - hist_B\right)^2}{hist_A + hist_B}\]
Parameters:
  • histA – histogram A
  • histB – histogram B (which A compares to)
  • eps – an epsilon for non-zero division
Returns:

the distance between the histograms
Return type:

np.ndarray
Utils.MyTools.chooseLargestContours(contours, labelProp, minArea)[source]¶

leaves only contours with area larger than minArea :param contours: list of contours :param labelProp: properties of labeled area :param minArea: minimal area needed :return: list of “large” contours

Utils.MyTools.chunking_dot(big_matrix, small_matrix, chunk_size=100)[source]¶
Utils.MyTools.computeImageDerivatives(img, order, **kwargs)[source]¶

Computes image derivatives up to order 2.

Parameters:
  • img – the image to which the derivatives should be computed
  • order – order needed (1 or 2)
  • ksize – filter kernel size (1, 3, 5, or 7)
  • resolution – kernel resolution
  • sigma – sigma for gaussian blurring. Default: 1. If sigma=0 no smoothing is carried out
  • window – tuple of window size for blurring
Returns:

tuple of the derivatives in the following order: (dx, dy, dxx, dyy, dxy)
Utils.MyTools.computeImageDerivatives_numeric(img, order, ksize=3, sigma=1.0, resolution=1.0, blur_window=(0, 0), **kwargs)[source]¶

Computes numeric image derivatives up to order 2.

Parameters:
  • img (np.array) – the image to which the derivatives should be computed
  • order (int) – order needed (1 or 2)
  • ksize (int) – size of the differentiation window
  • resolution (float) – kernel resolution
  • sigma (float) – sigma for gaussian blurring. Default: 1. If sigma=0 no smoothing is carried out
  • blur_window (tuple) – tuple of window size for blurring
Returns:

tuple of the derivatives in the following order: (dx, dy, dxx, dyy, dxy)

Note

Eq. numbers from Amit Baruch Dissertation

Utils.MyTools.computeImageGradient(I, **kwargs)[source]¶

Computes the gradient to a given image

Parameters:
  • I – image to which the gradient is computed
  • ksize – kernel size, for blurring and derivatives
  • sigma – sigma for LoG gradient
  • gradientType – ‘L1’ L1 norm of grad(I); ‘L2’ L2-norm of grad(I); ‘LoG’ Laplacian of gaussian
Returns:

an image of the gradient magnitude
Utils.MyTools.computeImageGradient_numeric(img, gradientType='L1', ksize=3, sigma=1, resolution=1, blur_window=(0, 0), **kwargs)[source]¶
Parameters:
  • img (np.array) – the image to which the derivatives should be computed
  • gradientType (str) – ‘L1’ L1 norm of grad(I); ‘L2’ L2-norm of grad(I); ‘LoG’ Laplacian of gaussian
  • ksize (int) – size of the differentiation window
  • resolution (float) – kernel resolution
  • sigma (float) – sigma for gaussian blurring. Default: 1. If sigma=0 no smoothing is carried out
  • blur_window (tuple) – tuple of window size for blurring
Returns:

an image of the gradient magnitude
Return type:

np.array
Utils.MyTools.connected_components_filtering(image, min_area=None, connectivity=8)[source]¶

Filter an image using connected components according to maximal area size

Parameters:
  • image (np.array) – the image ro filter
  • max_area (int) – the minimum allowed area. If None, it will be the median area of the CC.
  • connectivity – the connectivity type (4/8). Default: 8
Returns:

filtered image
Return type:

np.array

Parameters:curve – pyplot.2Dline
Returns:geopandas GeoSeries of a polygon
Utils.MyTools.curveCentralDerivatives(c, repartition=5)[source]¶

Computes the first and second central derivative of a curve :param c: curve points, not necessarily arc-length :param repartition: the step for repartition. if negative does not change the curve partition :return: tuple, (c’, c”)

Utils.MyTools.curves2D_toGeoDataframe(curves)[source]¶

Returns:geodataframe of the polygons
Return type:gpd.GeoDataFrame
Utils.MyTools.draw_contours(func, ax, img, hold=False, blob_size=5, color_random=False, **kwargs)[source]¶

Draws the contours of a specific iteration

Parameters:
  • func (np.ndarray) – the function which contours should be drawn
  • ax (plt.axes) – the axes to draw upon
  • image – the image on which the contours will be drawn
  • hold (bool) – erase image from previous drawings or not. Default: False
  • color (str or bool) – the color which the contour will be drawn. Default: random for each curve (send True)
  • linewidth – the line width of the curves. Default: 1
  • blob_size – the minimal area of a contour to draw
Returns:

the figure
Utils.MyTools.eig(matrix)[source]¶

Computes eigenvalues and eigenvectors and returns them sorted from smallest eigenvalues to largest

Parameters:matrix (nd-array) – matrix to compute the eigenvalues and eigenvectors
Return eigenValues, eigenVectors:
 sorted from small to large

Utils.MyTools.interpolate_data(data, attribute_data, resolution, func=<class 'scipy.interpolate.ndgriddata.NearestNDInterpolator'>, **kwargs)[source]¶

Interpolate data according to a specific attribute

Parameters:
  • data (np.ndarray) – the table to interpolate. Should have at least x,y and an attribute to interpolate (z or other)
  • attribute_data – values to interpolate
  • func (function) – the function with which the data will be interpolated. Default: nearest neighbors
  • kwargs – dictionary for function’s arguments
Returns:

interpolated data

Convert numerical zero to zero

Parameters:
  • array (np.array) – an array with various parameters
  • eps (float) – a thershold below which the number is zero (default: 1e-5
Returns:

the same array with zeros instead of \(|x|<eps\)
Return type:

np.array
Utils.MyTools.repartitionCurve(c, dh)[source]¶

Re-partitions the curve according to dh :param c: curve :param dh: length between points :return: the re-partitioned curve

Utils.MyTools.scale_values(array, min=0.0, max=1.0)[source]¶

Scale values between min and max range

\[f_{new} = \frac{(max-min) (f-f_{min})}{f_{max}-f_{min}} + min\]
Parameters:
  • array (np.array) – the array that will be re-scaled
  • min (float) – the minimal value of the range (default: 0)
  • max (float) – the maximal value of the range (default: 1)
Returns:

rescaled array
Return type:

np.array
